metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Machine Learning - Linear Regression
Regression
The term regression is used when you try to find the relationship between variables.
content.html: The term regression is used when you try to find the relationship between variables.

content.text: In Machine Learning, and in statistical modeling, that relationship is used to predict the outcome of future events.
content.html: In Machine Learning, and in statistical modeling, that relationship is used to predict the outcome of future events.

content.text: Linear Regression
Linear regression uses the relationship between the data-points to draw a straight line through all them.
content.html: Linear regression uses the relationship between the data-points to draw a straight line through all them.

content.text: This line can be used to predict future values.
content.html: This line can be used to predict future values.

content.text: In Machine Learning, predicting the future is very important.
content.html: In Machine Learning, predicting the future is very important.

content.text: How Does it Work?
Python has methods for finding a relationship between data-points and to draw a line of linear regression. We will show you how to use these methods instead of going through the mathematic formula.
content.html: Python has methods for finding a relationship between data-points and to draw a line of linear regression. We will show you how to use these methods instead of going through the mathematic formula.

content.text: In the example below, the x-axis represents age, and the y-axis represents speed. We have registered the age and speed of 13 cars as they were passing a tollbooth. Let us see if the data we collected could be used in a linear regression:
content.html: In the example below, the x-axis represents age, and the y-axis represents speed. We have registered the age and speed of 13 cars as they were passing a tollbooth. Let us see if the data we collected could be used in a linear regression:

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = [5,7,8,7,2,17,2,9,4,11,12,9,6]
y = [99,86,87,88,111,86,103,87,94,78,77,85,86]

plt.scatter(x, y)
plt.show()

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltfrom scipy import stats
  x = [5,7,8,7,2,17,2,9,4,11,12,9,6]y = 
  [99,86,87,88,111,86,103,87,94,78,77,85,86]slope, intercept, r, 
  p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)def myfunc(x):  
  return slope * x + interceptmymodel = list(map(myfunc, x))
  plt.scatter(x, y)plt.plot(x, mymodel)plt.show()

p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)def myfunc(x):
return slope * x + interceptmymodel = list(map(myfunc, x))
plt.scatter(x, y)plt.plot(x, mymodel)plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy import stats

x = [5,7,8,7,2,17,2,9,4,11,12,9,6]
y = [99,86,87,88,111,86,103,87,94,78,77,85,86]

slope, intercept, r, p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)

def myfunc(x):
  return slope * x + intercept

mymodel = list(map(myfunc, x))

plt.scatter(x, y)
plt.plot(x, mymodel)
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

  p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)def myfunc(x):  
  return slope * x + interceptmymodel = list(map(myfunc, x))
  plt.scatter(x, y)plt.plot(x, mymodel)plt.show()

content.text: Example Explained
Import the modules you need.
content.html: Import the modules you need.

content.text: You can learn about the Matplotlib module in our Matplotlib Tutorial .
content.html: You can learn about the Matplotlib module in our Matplotlib Tutorial.

content.text: You can learn about the SciPy module in our SciPy Tutorial .
content.html: You can learn about the SciPy module in our SciPy Tutorial.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltfrom scipy 
  import stats

content.code: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt from scipy import stats

import matplotlib.pyplot as pltfrom scipy 
  import stats

content.text: Create the arrays that represent the values of the x and y axis:
content.html: Create the arrays that represent the values of the x and y axis:

content.text: Execute a method that returns some important key values of Linear Regression:
content.html: Execute a method that returns some important key values of Linear Regression:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
slope, intercept, r, 
  p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)

content.code: slope, intercept, r, p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
slope, intercept, r, 
  p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)

content.text: Create a function that uses the slope and intercept values to return a new value. This new value represents where on the y-axis the corresponding x value will be placed:
content.html: Create a function that uses the slope and intercept values to return a new value. This new value represents where on the y-axis the corresponding x value will be placed:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def myfunc(x):
  return slope * x + intercept

content.code: def myfunc(x): return slope * x + intercept

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def myfunc(x):
  return slope * x + intercept

content.text: Run each value of the x array through the function. This will result in a new array with new values for the y-axis:
content.html: Run each value of the x array through the function. This will result in a new array with new values for the y-axis:

content.text: Draw the original scatter plot:
content.html: Draw the original scatter plot:

content.text: Draw the line of linear regression:
content.html: Draw the line of linear regression:

content.text: Display the diagram:
content.html: Display the diagram:

content.text: R for Relationship
It is important to know how the relationship between the values of the x-axis and the values of the y-axis is, if there are no relationship the linear regression can not be used to predict anything.
content.html: It is important to know how the relationship between the values of the x-axis and the values of the y-axis is, if there are no relationship the linear regression can not be used to predict anything.

content.text: This relationship - the coefficient of correlation - is called r .
content.html: This relationship - the coefficient of correlation - is called r.

content.text: The r value ranges from -1 to 1, where 0 means no relationship, and 1 (and -1) means 100% related.
content.html: The r value ranges from -1 to 1, where 0 means no relationship, and 1 (and -1) means 100% related.

content.text: Python and the Scipy module will compute this value for you, all you have to do is feed it with the x and y values.
content.html: Python and the Scipy module will compute this value for you, all you have to do is feed it with the x and y values.

  [5,7,8,7,2,17,2,9,4,11,12,9,6]y = 
  [99,86,87,88,111,86,103,87,94,78,77,85,86]slope, intercept, r, 
  p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)print(r)

content.code_html:
from scipy import stats

x = [5,7,8,7,2,17,2,9,4,11,12,9,6]
y = [99,86,87,88,111,86,103,87,94,78,77,85,86]

slope, intercept, r, p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)

print(r)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
from scipy import statsx = 
  [5,7,8,7,2,17,2,9,4,11,12,9,6]y = 
  [99,86,87,88,111,86,103,87,94,78,77,85,86]slope, intercept, r, 
  p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)print(r)

content.text: Note: The result -0.76 shows that there is a relationship, not perfect, but it indicates that we could use linear regression in future predictions.
content.html: Note: The result -0.76 shows that there is a relationship, not perfect, but it indicates that we could use linear regression in future predictions.

content.text: Predict Future Values
Now we can use the information we have gathered to predict future values.
content.html: Now we can use the information we have gathered to predict future values.

content.text: Example: Let us try to predict the speed of a 10 years old car.
content.html: Example: Let us try to predict the speed of a 10 years old car.

content.text: To do so, we need the same myfunc() function from the example above:
content.html: To do so, we need the same myfunc() function from the example above:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def myfunc(x):
  return slope * x + intercept

content.code: def myfunc(x): return slope * x + intercept

  return slope * x + intercept

  print(speed)

content.text: The example predicted a speed at 85.6, which we also could read from the diagram:
content.html: The example predicted a speed at 85.6, which we also could read from the diagram:

content.text: Bad Fit?
Let us create an example where linear regression would not be the best method to predict future values.
content.html: Let us create an example where linear regression would not be the best method to predict future values.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as pltfrom scipy import stats
  x = [89,43,36,36,95,10,66,34,38,20,26,29,48,64,6,5,36,66,72,40]y = 
  [21,46,3,35,67,95,53,72,58,10,26,34,90,33,38,20,56,2,47,15]slope, 
  intercept, r, p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)def 
  myfunc(x):  return slope * x + interceptmymodel = list(map(myfunc, 
  x))plt.scatter(x, y)plt.plot(x, mymodel)plt.show()

content.text: And the r for relationship?
content.html: And the r for relationship?

content.code_html:
import numpy
from scipy import stats

x = [89,43,36,36,95,10,66,34,38,20,26,29,48,64,6,5,36,66,72,40]
y = [21,46,3,35,67,95,53,72,58,10,26,34,90,33,38,20,56,2,47,15]

slope, intercept, r, p, std_err = stats.linregress(x, y)

print(r)

content.text: The result: 0.013 indicates a very bad relationship, and tells us that this data set is not suitable for linear regression.
content.html: The result: 0.013 indicates a very bad relationship, and tells us that this data set is not suitable for linear regression.
